@granders For local testing, I run the tests in docker containers. Apart from running on a lower-spec machine, it also enables us to run tests in an environment that is closer to our deployment environment. And this worked quite well until quite recently. But now there seems to be more timing issues. Like the one @benstopford pointed out above. I ran the tests with the lower producer throughput that Ben recommended on the Confluent Jenkins kafka_system_test_branch_builder and quite a few tests failed. I think we need to understand why these tests are so timing-sensitive before committing this.

@rhauch @ymatsuda I think I agree with Randall with the impact on programmability, and I am still pondering on the necessity of this new API. I was thinking about another case related to partitioning. It is not for user-friendliness but about supporting aggregations in the KStream DSL:
1. KStream topology contains a bunch of high-level operations like Map, Filter, Join, Aggregate is translated into the lower-level Processor topology in runtime.
2. To support groupBy-Aggregate, the current design is to use an intermediate Kafka topic to store aggregated values per partition, such that the aggregation operators can compute their own aggregates and send the update records to various partitions according to their aggregate key, and another "merge" operators that reads the update records per partition and merge the updates that were sent from different aggregation operations based on their own partitions.
3. So this requires the translated topology to include a Sink node after the aggregation Operator node, which is able to send to different partitions according to their key. In common cases the default producer partitioner that does the murmur hashcode on the key should be fine, but we may want to choose a more advanced partitioner to reduce data skewness, etc.

So I am wondering, what scenarios would you require a specific partitioner for each topic, rather than a general partitioner that just guarantees same-key-goes-to-same-partition (like the default partitioner)? For now I feel it may be necessary for the end sink nodes, i.e. the Kafka topics that are the final outputs of Kafka Streams, but for intermediate topics they may not be required. 

Or if the original key is a combo of multiple fields (e.g. a GenericRecord of ServiceCallEventID) where the partitioning is only related to one of its field (e.g. string ServiceName inside ServiceCallEventID), then we can do a `map` operator to extract the fields first then `forward to sink`, but admittedly this requires storing the message with the enforced key in Kafka as well.

Thoughts?

@rajinisivaram - I actually got the same failures locally that you see on EC2. I'm not entirely sure why this should happen. Lowering the throughput should make things better (and has done in other tests). There must be something deeper going on. I'll take a closer look tomorrow. 
On the other point - ideally we'll get ourselves into a position where anyone can run these tests locally in a reliable manner. It's a bit difficult to use EC2 because of the feedback cycle being so slow. A build server that runs the 'local vm' version may be the best option, so we know these tests work run locally. But that will take some extra effort, and maybe hardware. We should consolidate on one way though if possible.

> So I am wondering, what scenarios would you require a specific partitioner for each topic, rather than a general partitioner that just guarantees same-key-goes-to-same-partition (like the default partitioner)? For now I feel it may be necessary for the end sink nodes, i.e. the Kafka topics that are the final outputs of Kafka Streams, but for intermediate topics they may not be required.

@guozhangwang, one scenario that I run into frequently is to partition by subset of a hierarchical key. For example, if a key for a "row" or entity is composed of multiple hierarchical parts such as "`<database>/<collection>/<group>/<row>`", then a topic consumed by multiple instances of a stateful processor (with stateful local storage) requires message keys with the full ID so that the topics can be garbage collected. However, for scalability reasons there are multiple processor instances, and because they're stateful partitioning is required to ensure that, for example, all rows within a particular collection always go to the same processor instance. In that case, the partitioning would be based upon the "`<database>/<collection>`" part of the key. However, this is not universal: other services within the same system have their own processors and usually need different partitioning schemes (e.g., at the database level for billing, or even at the group level for notifications).

> Or if the original key is a combo of multiple fields (e.g. a GenericRecord of ServiceCallEventID) where the partitioning is only related to one of its field (e.g. string ServiceName inside ServiceCallEventID), then we can do a map operator to extract the fields first then forward to sink, but admittedly this requires storing the message with the enforced key in Kafka as well.

Handling partitioning via the topology/DSL seems to be a bit odd. Normally the topology deals with key-value pairs, and if part of the topology (e.g., a map node just before a sink) converted the key to a partition-able key then the message lost its original key. To do this, you'd need the topology to be able to track key-partitionkey-value triples, and that's pretty different than what Kafka Streams is doing (and likely overkill for many situations).

IMO partitioning should be orthogonal to the topology structure, and it really should be determined at the sink. Thus, I'm still going to try to advocate for a solution like this PR.
@guozhangwang Would you have time to review this patch? @onurkaraman has reviewed this patch. @jjkoshy would be on leave soon.
@fpj What do you think?

LGTM. Note though that we've only changed send TERM in the 3.5 and 3.6 branches (check ZOOKEEPER-2079).

Also, a slightly better approach might be to remember the process id rather grepping, but maybe you don't want to do this change in this jira.

> LGTM. Note though that we've only changed send TERM in the 3.5 and 3.6 branches (check ZOOKEEPER-2079).

Yes, that's why I made the note on possible side effects yes/no in the JIRA ticket, @fpj.

> Also, a slightly better approach might be to remember the process id rather grepping, but maybe you don't want to do this change in this jira.

Exactly.  Switching to pid-tracking (and one can debate whether that's a good idea in the first place) would also require changing e.g. the Kafka start/stop scripts.  Hence I wanted to be minimally invasive with this PR with regards to the existing implementation.
Yeah, pid tracking would be good to discuss in a separate JIRA (I also thought of that).

PS:  Reading [ZOOKEEPER-2079](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ZOOKEEPER-2079) I noticed that change was from SIGKILL (`-9`) to SIGTERM, whereas in our case we move from SIGINT (not as harsh as SIGKILL) to SIGTERM.
@fpj: Ah, sorry.  So that means going from SIGINT to SIGTERM (SIGTERM is also less harsh then SIGKILL) should not be a problem then.
Thoughts @granthenke, @ewencp?

Thanks for the PR, the way it's done at the moment is certainly problematic. I am not sure why we are loading these libraries via reflection though given that we specify the dependencies in our build for the clients library:

``` groovy
compile 'org.xerial.snappy:snappy-java:1.1.2'
compile 'net.jpountz.lz4:lz4:1.2.0'
```

It seems like this would only benefit people who exclude the transitive dependency on their builds. @guozhangwang, @junrao what are your thoughts?

@rajinisivaram Does `Files.createTempDirectory` guarantee atomic uniqueness? I cannot find it in the Java docs though it claims `createTempFile` does.
Seems like a good change. Probably a good idea to backport it to the 0.9.0 branch. @junrao, maybe you could review this?
Thanks for the patch. The changes look reasonably. Could you explain a bit more how you run into this issue? The consumer library should always send requests with the correct array size.

@junrao We ran into the issue when we upgraded one of our clusters to the latest version of Kafka from a version (built from trunk) that was a couple of months old. One of the clients was using an old client jar where the schema was no longer valid. This is not an issue when the client jars are at the right level, but we want to guard against large memory allocations that can result in denial-of-service since our servers are on the public internet.

@guozhangwang @ijuma  Thank you for reviewing the changes. `Files.createTempDirectory` uses `Files.createDirectory` in a loop under the covers. And the docs for `Files.createDirectory` says:

> Creates a new and empty file, failing if the file already exists. The check for the existence of the file and the creation of the new file if it does not exist are a single operation that is atomic with respect to all other filesystem activities that might affect the directory.
LGTM
@rajinisivaram @ijuma I am a bit concerned about having more than one concurrent shutdown hook thread trying to delete the file since `File.delete()` may not be atomic.
@guozhangwang @rajinisivaram Maybe we could rename `tempPartitionLogDir` to `randomPartitionLogDir`, remove the shutdown hook and document that deletion must be done by the caller.
Thanks for the patch. LGTM. Since this shouldn't happen on releases jars, we will commit this to trunk.

I've hit a problem when implementing a test for ssl client required/requested, which I solved by simulating a CA signing certificates in `TestSslUtils`. It is quite hard to debug such issues and what got me to implement this solutions was both documentation and reports of CA signing issues on the Web. The problem I observed specifically was that the server was throwing a `SSLPeerUnverifiedException`, which was leading to the test failure.

I suspected that the self-signing was not really working in `TestSslUtils` and gave a try to this implementing this simulated CA. It works for me locally, and it makes sense, but I wonder if anyone else has a concern with this change.

@junrao what's our policy with regards to denial of service security issues (like this one)? With the security work and quotas, people may think that the broker can be protected against misbehaving clients. From that perspective, I'd say that we would want to backport this to 0.9.0. But perhaps we think it's too soon to offer such guarantees.
@guozhangwang @ijuma Have made the change suggested by @ijuma  above.
Quick question: are all the tests passing?

I spent some time investigating why we needed the CAroot change here and I found the issue. In `IntegrationTestHarness.setUp`, we need to call `producerSecurityConfigs` and `consumerSecurityConfigs` before we call `super.setUp`. The reason is that those calls populate the truststore file with the client certificates and `super.setUp` starts the brokers (which load the truststore file on start-up). It goes without saying that this is not obvious at all! With the suggested change, we don't need the CAroot changes anymore (we may still want them, but the tests pass without them).

``` scala
    val ps = TestUtils.producerSecurityConfigs(securityProtocol, trustStoreFile)
    val cs = TestUtils.consumerSecurityConfigs(securityProtocol, trustStoreFile)
    super.setUp()
    producerConfig.put(ProducerConfig.BOOTSTRAP_SERVERS_CONFIG, brokerList)
    producerConfig.put(ProducerConfig.KEY_SERIALIZER_CLASS_CONFIG, classOf[org.apache.kafka.common.serialization.ByteArraySerializer])
    producerConfig.put(ProducerConfig.VALUE_SERIALIZER_CLASS_CONFIG, classOf[org.apache.kafka.common.serialization.ByteArraySerializer])
    producerConfig.putAll(ps)
    consumerConfig.put(ConsumerConfig.BOOTSTRAP_SERVERS_CONFIG, brokerList)
    consumerConfig.put(ConsumerConfig.KEY_DESERIALIZER_CLASS_CONFIG, classOf[org.apache.kafka.common.serialization.ByteArrayDeserializer])
    consumerConfig.put(ConsumerConfig.VALUE_DESERIALIZER_CLASS_CONFIG, classOf[org.apache.kafka.common.serialization.ByteArrayDeserializer])
    consumerConfig.putAll(cs)
```
Thanks, LGTM.
LGTM.

@logarithm @ijuma Some background about using reflections: the old snappy libraries do not work with some solaris systems (https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/orient-database/-gDSvAu39iw) and we saw issues like this back at LinkedIn cc @junrao. That is the main reason we used reflections.

This issue seems fixed in the newer snappy versions. I think we should fix it.
